text: So there we have an ar, er, and ir verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we saw our verbs form one group and er, ir verbs form another group.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But we have one time in the entire Spanish language where there is a difference between er and ir verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Otherwise they are always forming one group.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But just one occasion in the whole Spanish language where there is a difference between them.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How do you say we speak or we are speaking?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say we eat or we are eating?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for er verbs we use emos for we in the present.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And for ir verbs we use imos for we in the present.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But of course for the other versions they are using the same endings.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Again we are using an e.

text: They eat or you guys eat?

speaker: Speaker 1

text: Not eat but it I t.

text: There's a couple of interesting and useful things we can do with lo, it in Spanish which we can't do in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, when you want to say the interesting thing, the complicated thing is, the interesting thing is, the difficult thing about that is.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Instead of saying the word for thing in Spanish, you can just say, for example, lo interesante.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Lo interesante means the interesting thing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you get the structure, the interesting thing with lo interesante.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, for example, the interesting thing is that they live here?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The interesting thing is that they live here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Lo interesante es que viven aquí.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: Lo interesante es que viven aquí.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say the interesting thing is that they live together?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, the word for together in Spanish is, junto.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is the singular masculine version.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It doesn't sound like it but when you realize that junto is with J, then you can see how it's related to junction in English and join.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The interesting thing is that they live together.

text: Lo interesante es que viven junto.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: Lo interesante es que viven juntos.

text: Or if they were two females, you would say?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Lo interesante es que viven juntas.

text: The interesting thing is that they live together.

speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, if you wanted to say the easy thing, how would you say that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Lo fácil and then you will carry on.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we can say the easy thing is that they come together.

text: The easy thing is that they come together.

text: So, don't go from venir to I version to they version.

text: What you want to do is focus your thoughts on just what you have in front of you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Which is going from venir to the they form.

text: And try to build it as it should be.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then when you get that result, then have a look at maybe if it's irregular, if it doesn't feel right.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The I one though, my mind is trying to remember.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: If you don't need it now, it shouldn't be important for you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because with everything you will remember, you will remember something similar that you don't remember.

text: If you let that occupy your thoughts, then you are going to block.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You need to be comfortable with a level of uncertainty to learn a language.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you want to have the whole panorama of the whole language before you start speaking, you will never start speaking.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And sooner or later we are going to come across again that thought that distracted us because we are going to want to say it.

text: And in that moment, we will sort it out.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, the more we do that, the more you are going to control this panorama of Spanish that makes you a little bit insecure right now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because you know so much and you feel like it's all floating around.

text: The easy thing is that they come together.

text: So, we can say lo bueno, the good thing, lo malo, the bad thing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Malo is bad like in malnutritioned.

text: Before we said de esta forma, in this way.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We could also say de esta manera, in this manner.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But, very very common in Spanish when we want to say like this, like that, is the word así.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Así means like this or like that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, if you want to say something like we don't speak like this, we don't speak in that way, you don't really need to say de esa manera or de esa forma.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can just take this wonderful shortcut for like this or like that, which is así.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, like this, like that, así.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we don't speak like that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't speak in that way.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Another interesting thing that we can do with lo, a useful structure we can make with lo, is lo de.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The combination of lo and de means like the thing about.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, we've seen how lo can sometimes replace thing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And lo de is like the thing about.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, if you wanted to say the thing about the party, you just say lo de la fiesta.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, if you want to say we are speaking about the thing about the party, not we are speaking about the party, but we are speaking about that issue of the party.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: That thing we know what we are referring to.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We are speaking about that business about the party.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or hablamos sobre, about, you could say that as well.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Hablamos sobre lo de la fiesta.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You could even say de, we speak of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Hablamos de lo de la fiesta.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can say that business about Juan.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, you could say I don't want to speak about Juan's business like this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I don't want to speak about Juan's business like this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And for Juan's business, you would just say?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, I don't want to speak about Juan's business like this?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: No quiero hablar de lo de Juan así.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: No quiero hablar de lo de Juan así.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or we could say no quiero hablar sobre lo de Juan así.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or just no quiero hablar lo de Juan así.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, lo de, we kind of want to see as a unit, meaning that thing about.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we've seen already that de can mean about.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, it's just it about, that thing about.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's used very often in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you will find it very useful.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, you could say, for example, I want to organize that thing tomorrow.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, I want to organize that thing about tomorrow.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Quiero organizar lo de la mañana.
speaker: Speaker 2

text: So, morning and tomorrow are the same word in Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you say la mañana, we can understand the morning.

text: But I don't want to organize it like this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But I don't want to organize it like this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But I don't want to organize it like this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or if you wanted to be more emphatic, you could replace así with de esta manera, de esta forma, of this way, of this form.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But así is the most common.

text: You will be hearing it all the time.
